description.text:
This proyect allow to create a cheap trackballl mouse starting from a conventional optical Mouse. A Trackball mouse allow people with hand/arm movement problems to control a computer.

It is very important for the function of the trackball mouse that the center of the mouse's laser should touch (or be very near) to the ball.

You will need to download this software (http://hp.vector.co.jp/authors/VA026826/ ) in order to reverse the direction of the mouse.Also it is recommended slow down the mouse speed.

This object was made for the "Mutual de Seguridad C.Ch.C" from Chile. In a project of the Direction of innovation and development, and the Neuro rehabilitation institute.

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.3mm

Infill:

15

Notes:

The resolution for all parts except the ball is 0.3mm. The ball should be very smooth, so it is recommended to print it with 0.1mm resolution and sand it after print.

Assemble
  1. Take off the circuit of an optic mouse. 2. Weld wires to each pin of the switch of the right and left button. 3. Weld a flat switch at the end of the wires (One for each button). 4. Put the circuit inside the "Box Mouse", you can fix it with silicone or melt some PLA like in the picture. 5. Fix the "Box Mouse" to the "Box Big". 6. Fix the "Switch Base" on the "Box Big" and fix the flat switch to them. 7. Put over the flat switch the printed Switch, and fix the "Ball Base" where is indicated in the picture. 8. Place the Ball over. 9 Fix the "Box Top". 10. Optionally you can stick something anti-slip at the bottom

comments.text:
He hecho una carcasa para trackball ergonómica en la que encaja el mecanismo interno de tu diseño (o cualquier otro con una bola redimensionada al mismo tamaño de 5 cm.). El diseño es más ergonómico y a la medida exacta de la mano de una persona en concreto con una limitación funcional en el rango de movimiento del dedo pulgar.
La carcasa permite una posición más cómoda de la mano en posición de reposo para prevenir lesiones posturales.
Creo que puede ser de tu interés: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2785014
El acabado no es muy elegante seguramente. Es mi primer diseño :-)
Un saludo cordial

This is a two-part, 3D-printable ROV thruster design, indended to print on hobbyist-grade fused-filament printers. The name, a silly pun, is a combination of Creators name (Morgan) and the name of the guy who made the previous version (Godø).

The two pieces will come out slightly stuck together but they have less chance of peeling and warping that way and they're easy to separate from the top with a knife after the print is done. For deep water use, we recommended printing at 100% infill.

The two parts can be assembled with a nut and a bolt, 1/4"-28 x 1" long.

It has a concave bottom to provide for mounting onto the 4" OD aluminum tube that the Seeker ROV uses.

Original on GitHUb
https://github.com/SV-Seeker/Mor-Go-Thruster

comments.author: willie013

comments.text: It does take some force but once together they are secure. What worked for me is lean one side in, then on the other side pull up on the outside tab and push in on the inside tab while pushing to get them under each other. Hope that makes sense.

comments.text: Thanks for the swift reply! I got them together, they fit really well! Did you use the stiff wires that came with the bed or did you replace them for some better silicone wires to make sure the chain doesn't get stuck?

Another 1.75mm filament clip, this one uses a micro-sized binder clip, and should attach to almost any spool and is easy to reposition.  I'm using micro sized Swinton and Acco sized binder clips.  
There are two versions, the smaller one probably needs to be printed in PET as it flexes a lot when it's attached.  The larger one will probably work in ABS and is easier to attach.

description.text:
Do you have an acrylic Geeetech i3 Pro B?

Do you want to move your LCD control panel to the front of the Y axis ala Prusa i3?

Do you not need a complete enclosure?

Give this a go!

These use the existing M10 threaded rod, washers and nuts at the front of the Y axis and 2x 10mm long self tapping philips head screws which came with the printer.

Use the existing acrylic spacer parts by turning them upside down so that the mounting screw holes appear at the top.

WARNING
Only use these if the printer is on a level surface large enough for the front edge of the LCD acrylic surround to rest on. These mounts WILL SNAP if the front of that piece is not supported.

The guiro is a Latin American percussion instrument consisting of an open-ended, hollow gourd with parallel notches cut in one side. It is played by rubbing a stick or tines along the notches to produce a ratchet sound.

Printer Brand:

LulzBot

Printer:

Mini

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Inspiration

We were assigned to make an instrument in our class, and it only needed to have two or more parts. I decided to keep things simple so I went with a percussion instrument. This was an interesting instrument so I went with this.

History

The guiro is commonly used in Puerto Rican, Cuban and other forms of Latin American music, and plays a key role in the typical rhythm section of important genres like son, trova and salsa.

Process

I made an ellipse and put a hole through it, then I used cylinders and BooleanDifference to create the ridges along the four sides. The stick was just a Truncated Cone with the top and bottom both filleted. Some obstacles I faced were trying to fillet the edges of the hole, but it never worked so I gave up.

Toby O:

This is a new spin to the beloved Toby-X using some cool new concepts introduced by Dquad Obsession (full credit for this concept goes to the designer of the Dquad Obsession). The center plates should be printed in either ABS, PLA + or PETG. My personal choice is PLA + and I use the THUGH middle plate for extra strength. The arms should not be 3d-printed, instead use the compatible ZMR-250 carbon fiber arms. For best results I printed the oval parts in TPU at 120% extrusion multiplier, 3 walls all around and 30% infill with supports.

UPDATE:

new v2 version adds a fourth standoff for extra rigidity and so it's compatible with any D-Obsession accessories, for anyone interested in making accessories or mounts the last 2 standoffs are set 20mm apart at an angle of 30 degrees with respect to the bottom plates. Also included in the files, a simple vtx antenna mount designed by DanThompson880.

This is a great introduction to 3D printer for the students. I personally used this lesson with 5th grade students.

We were beginning our unit on 3D design. I recorded videos to help take them through the steps of using Tinkercad to create a keychain. The steps are below

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator (5th Generation)

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Infill:

20%
Students do not need any background. This is an introduction to Tinkercad shapes and 3D printing.

Steps to Make Keychain with students The steps were as follows
  • Use the cylinder or rectangle and make the dimmensions 51mm x 25mm
  • Use the text tool to personalize. Decide if you want to keep it solid and raise it up or make the text a hole.
  • Set the text into the keychain. Group everything together.
  • Size it to 6.35mm high (y)
  • Use the cylinder hole and create an 8mm hole for the keychain.
  • Students submitted STL file and Screenshot of dimensions through Schoology
80 minutes (2 x 40min classes)

This is a litle modification to have better supports for rubbers

A simple gauge used to measure the length of a bike chain.

One side is the length of 6 new links, the other shows when the chain has stretched more than 0.5% and needs replacing.

You want your chain to fit one side and be too tight for the other. If it easily fits both then its time to replace your chain!

My other gauge will show if the chains so worn that the cassette and chainrings require replacing too - but if your chain is slack on both sides of this gauge chances are you're past the point of a cheap fix!

Use one or two more shells than usual when printing, use a dark coloured filament as it will get dirty quickly.

Enjoy!

Edit:

Updated to reflect comments received and remixes submitted - should print more easily and work marginally better now!

Designed on Solidworks.

Trial printed on a Flashforge Dreamer.

Chain measurements found on: http://miketechinfo.com/SRAM/chains2.htm#Chain%20wear

description.text:
Very Customizable Fidget Spinner

Customize:

  • type of weights: 5/16", 3/8", 1/2" nut, M8, M10, M12 nut, 608 bearing, 5/16", 3/8", 1/2", 5/8" loose ball bearing, US penny, nickel, dime or quarter, M4 square nut
  • number of rays
  • number of weights per ray
  • edge roundness (radius)
  • tapering of rays
  • glue grooves

Update 2017-09-29

Allow for ISO 4032 M10 (16mm) and M12 (18mm) hex nuts along with the old DIN 934 M10 (17mm) and M12 (19mm). Thanks to jnse for reporting the problem.

Update 2017-08-17

Added "minimal" ray style that just consists of the weight frame. If using an extended ray with one weight per ray, a thin bar will connect the weight to the center.

Update 2017-05-03

added M4 square nuts as suggested by nattrassj12

Update 2017-04-25

  • added the option to use 5/16" (8mm) loose ball bearings
  • added the option for horizontal glue grooves for center 608 bearing and ray weights

Update 2017-04-11

added the option to use loose ball bearings: 3/8", 1/2", and 5/8" (tested with 1/2" and 5/8"); for a heavy, long spinning spinner. Thanks to stolli666 for the suggestion.

Update 2017-03-27

added option to taper rays or not; without tapering, the ray will be more rectangular and less triangular

Update 2017-03-02

  • added M10 and M12 nut sizes
  • fixed low resolution bug

Update 2017-02-23

  • added 3/8" and 1/2" nut choices for weights
  • nuts will protrude but didn't want to require supports or have an asymmetrical frame

Update 2017-02-15

  • added the ability to extend the ray length when using only 1 weight per ray
  • added coins to type type of weights: 4 quarters, 5 dimes, 3 nickels or 4 pennies. But I prefer nuts or bearings for weights.

Notes:

  • A 4 ray, 1 weight per ray, 5/16" nut, 2.5mm radius version is very compact (easy one-handed spin) and fun! Give it a try.
  • Customizer might time out but the Create Thing button still works
  • I like using vise grips to install hardware
  • Cheap 5/16" hex nuts from Amazon
  • if a nut is loose in a PLA frame, dip nut in frame into hot water to shrink frame around nut
  • See my collection of all of my fidget spinner designs.

comments.text:

Sorry you're having problems. Have you tried hot water yet? When I have loose nuts, I heat up some water in the microwave for 2 minutes and dunk each nut in the PLA frame in the water for around 10 seconds and this tightens things up. Then I let it cool on its own. Careful not to burn yourself. Glue should work too.
In the description, I wrote, "if a nut is loose in a PLA frame, dip nut in frame into hot water to shrink frame around nut."

title: Anet A8 frame stabilizer anti wobble z-axis mod

description.text:
Anet A8 frame stabilizer for the z-axis (anti wobble mod)                                
           One optimized version for reduced print time, one solid version                       
 Check the scaling before you print (CURA for gods sake stop auto scaling my prints)   
  I recommend Leo_N backets for this mod http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1872162.


Hi there,
This is my iteration of a frame stabilizer. Yes there are other ones already, i know....
but have you actually SEEN THEM? Seriously. Ever single one has geometric holes in them, from circles, over triangles, to hexagons. And not a single one is actually connected to the frame. WTF.

This one IS connected to the frame. Every part uses two screw holes that are already available. You will have to drill another two holes into the acrylic frame, and one into Leo_N's backets http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1872162.
You will also need five M3 screws with washers and nuts for each part.

This stabilizer doesn't has any geometric holes. They don't add any advantage to the print and only increase the print time. The "enhanced" version even uses a few grams less material than similar stabilizers with holes and is optimized for reduced print time. There is also a solid version available for improved esthetics, if you really think you need that (but it needs 20% longer for the print and 40% more material)

Printing Facts:
This is a long print, make sure everything works fine.
I recommend custom supports. If that is not available grid support with 0% infill works too. Though, you will need some time to clean up the print.

Enhanced Version
Print Time (60 mm/s) = 8 h
Material used (grid support 0%) = 110 g

Solid Version
Print Time (60 mm/s) = 10 h
Material used (grid support 0%) = 145 g

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2 mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Wall thickness 1.6 mm
bottom/ top layer thickness 1.2 mm
A brim is adviceable

description.text:
A custom detachable motor mount for the S800 reptile racing wing.

The original plans for the S800 called for glueing the motor mounting bolts underneath the mounting plate. I wanted to have to option of being able able to change out the motor if i needed to, so I designed detachable bracket.

I used m3 capscrews and nuts for attaching the mount to the mounting plate. Its hard to see from the pictures, but I had to epoxy the m3 nuts underneath the carbon fiber plate that they screw into.

I designed this in OpenSCAD so anyone can grab the source and edit if they want.

title: SIG Kilo 2000 Laser Rangefinder Tripod Mount

description.text:
Click here to see the Lens Covers for the Sig Kilo!

A quick note to those of you that think you can just download something from here and sell it as your own design. I released this under the Creative Commons license that requires Attribution AND non-commercial uses. That means you can't sell it, and you have to give the designer credit when it's used.

Here's a tripod mount for the SIG Kilo 2000 Laser Rangefinder. The only thing out there on the market currently is $75 and there's no way in hell I was going to spend that on this tripod mount. I used these inserts to mount it to the tripod because that's what I had laying around. That's what the model is designed to use. I've also included one that's threaded for 1/4"-20 UNC, which is the standard tripod thread.

I've included the Fusion 360 model, as usual, so you can make your own changes as you see fit.

UPDATE: After printing off a threaded version and having it work very well, I made a couple changes. I made the part 30mm thick rather than 25mm. This will grip the Kilo a bit better and also give a little more meat on both sides of the bottom holes. I deepened the anti-twist hole from 2.5mm to 5mm, and finally, I added a 1mm filet around the entire thing to soften the sharp edges. Finally, I uploaded the latest Fusion 360 file that contains all the changes.

UPDATE 2: I should probably just make this a work in progress... Anyway, I added another file with the SIG Kilo logo on it, just in case you wanted that.

UPDATE 3: On request, I've added a version that has an Arca-Swiss compatible dovetail while keeping the 1/4"-20 threads so you can choose how to mount it. I've also uploaded the F3D file of that design. The Arca-Swiss STLs are no logo, with logo, and with logo and loop on the side.

This is my first print, it was intended as a modification for my printer but realised that anyone with a Vector 3 could use it!

It follows the same appearance as the original spool holder but adds 10mm in length to allow for 1KG spools to be housed within the printer enclosure. The holes will need to be bored out a little to allow the screws to fit through. Infill is not necessary but will give strength; the original holder was designed for the supplied spool which when loaded wouldn't weigh as much as a separately bought reel.

Edit 13/03/17: Following the failure of the original print I have modified the model. The base has been increased to 4mm thick, including sockets for the nuts supplied with the original holder and reworked screw holes. I have braced the holder further by extending the holder to cover more of the base. I have yet to print this new version, but I would recommend thick top and bottom layers and infill.

remixed_from.title: Lm8uu X Carriage with Fan Mount for Prusa Mendel

title: Greg's X Carriage with Quick Change Clip System

description.text:
UPDATE: No longer a work in progress, as it did work just not well enough. Version 2 now exists and is by far superior. If you want to print one of these I do recomend going for the Quick-Twist Release Greg's X Carriage instead. After poking around on here for a while, I decided it's time to contribute. So without further ado hereâ€™s my modified X Carriage based on Greg's X-Carriage. Basically after seeing many complex quick change systems to switch extruders, I wanted something simpler. Essentially this is a way of changing extruders by using the existing hardware and nothing more. We do this by taking a slot and hole idea seen on many household items to mount to walls ect. (i.e. on the back of power boards) with a screw in the wall and hanging it off the head. Current design is a little finicky on bolts being exactly right. Thinking of adding an indent where the bolts should end up and a spring washer to pull em in tight but allow room to get em back out by pushing on the end of the bolt while twisting (current design has no lock so it can vibrate loose if not tensioned correctly). Also rearranged the belt stuff in the center as I changed the corners of the big hole so there is more plastic where the bolt head goes through next iteration may use a spacer to help with holding the bolt in just the right spot (my groove mount plate has holes slightly wrong so holds the bolts in place but on a machine with correct spacing there could be a problem). Also, everything is a little big atm slot and hole can be made a little narrower. A final note.
This has not had much testing yet, so only use it if you know what youâ€™re doing. It is also not fully parametric yet. Until it is more complete I won't be attaching the scad... soon (itâ€™s a bit of a mess atm) Also all credit where it's due to Greg and everyone else involved as this is essentially an addin file to replace the mounting holes. UPDATE: SCADs up. go nuts

Print it.
Note how far bolts that hold extruder are in. 
Replace current carriage with it.
Put the bolts back into extruder about as far as they were.
Put the bolt heads through the big holes.
..And twist.
If it won't twist bolts may be too tight so loosen. This will only work if the bolts are just right. Too loose and it will move about, too tight and you will break something.

comments.text: What if you add an indentation (not a full hole) for the cap of the screw to sit in when it's locked in position?  Then you only have to loosen the screws (maybe even just one) a little bit to allow the extruder to rotate freely.

description.text:
I wanted to make a tiny fan that I could power with the computer's USB port, using one of the hundreds of motors I've collected over the years from tearing apart old optical drives for recycling.

This fan uses a FF-030PK motor that's very common in DVD drives.

The motor's voltage varies, depending on the model, but for what I could find online it's either 5.5v max or 7v max, and in both cases it can be used with the USB port (5v).

I measured the current used by the fan with the propeller on, and it was around 150ma, which is fine for any USB spec, I believe (500ma on 1.0 and 2.0).

The propeller is printed flat and you need to manually bend it to the correct angle.

Designed using SketchUp. Source included.

description.text:
Wanted to make bearings fit into this spool holder I had already printed, so I made these little couplers that fit into the holes on the uprights, that also fit standard 608 bearings.

Print a simple rod to go between the two or perhaps find a long bolt that the filament spool can rest on. Since this incorporates bearings it should reduce most of the drag or pull.

Printer:

Deltaprintr Assembled

No

No

0.2mm

25%

Notes:

Printed on the Delta Go at 30mm/sec with AMZ3D yellow PLA, at 205 degrees. I needed a brim (most stuff does on the Delta Go) but if you have good adhesion you won't need it.

There are two slight chamfers that will allow you to slide the bearings into the coupler, and the coupler into the holder uprights so these should simply be friction-fit. This exact size JUST fit into the uprights and fit the bearings perfectly, but my tolerances might be different than yours. I've included the SketchUp and DS Mechanical raw files if you'd like to tweak the diameter to match your printer's tolerances.

description.text:
This is a thin coaster made for the underside of a crochet African flower granny square that my girlfriend made. We thought it was neat to be able to use her crafting and 3D printing idea to blend our hobbies. In an afternoon (minus the wait for glue) we were able to make a homemade gift.

The crochet pattern can be found here: http://flowers-dezdemon.xyz/2016/03/03/crochet-african-flower-pattern-helpful-when-making-the-stuffed-elephant-would/

The CAD I made can be found here: https://cad.onshape.com/documents/25b1b31e4b9d064ee8493a27/w/f959f5e94d690996db75c04d/e/ac3c00490ea5d0eee9d9b098

Printer:

Flashforge Dreamer

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

High

Infill:

None

Notes:

Print vertically with brim.

1. Brim removal

We used a razor blade to shave off the brim and 220 grit sandpaper to smooth the edges.

2. Crochet design attachment

We used Loctite transparent vinyl, fabric & plastic flexible adhesive and painted on the glue with a throw away brush or index card. The glue takes 2 hours to set.
The yarn used was Sugar'n Cream from Michaels, worsted weight 4 with a 4.5mm hook. Each square took around 30 minutes.

author: natethegreat108

description.text:
A beam support for a second floor overhang, watchtower, catwalk, or mezzanine.

Kudos to Printablescenery
http://www.printablescenery.com/product-category/rampage-system/
Rampage
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1821631
OpenLock 4.0
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1833963
DevonJones
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1882294

Design:
Using Devon Jones cut stone walls offers some advantages. The key is a consistent width and coursing. Having seen his OpenForge Multi-Floor concept (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1078471), I was looking in another direction. The OpenLock Clips allow a greater span, but until Printablescenery, released their wall design spec for second floors, there was really no other options. However to utilize their design, you need the nubs on top of your walls. Just does not fit aesthetically.
Thus, I created a concept beam one sided wall clip. (shown) Was "fat" but concept of single side overhang "clip" worked. Still should be reworked to allow side clips as the second floor just sets upon the beam, and does skid.
2nd Gen (shown) was really co-designed with the single side clip, one cross beam to support the second floor/mezz/overhang and kept in place with 2 braces. 2nd gen added holes to put in 3mm filament and spaced the holes to allow perpendicular floor spans in addition to wall overhang spans. Put the pins in the holes to match the base holes. This keeps the second floor from skidding around. Once the pins are in place it becomes easy to set up and remove.
3rd gen was an attempt to remove the "gap" created and was to use a half-clip and glue into the side of the support. Would create an odd spacing of floor clips and is only included to offer an idea for someone else in creating a specific/special design.
4th gen is the 2nd gen design with a 2mm gap spacing. Have not printed, but I think 2mm would be the smallest feasible gap as the support may not "hold"
5th Gen is a stand alone mezzanine. No gap and clips to additional floor tiles or walls. the negative with this design is printing upside down. (Printing the other designs upside down does not make a difference in the print quality) Have not printed, may need more space between the beams to fit on the wall, opposed to the "snap clip" that you get with V2 Support.
Cool Headphone wrap by Zach Moseley and I

title: Folgertech FT-5 X Idler upgrade
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Please note: For those with the newer version of the FT-5 with the new style idlers, I have uploaded a revised X idler lower body to accommodate the difference in hole sizes of the factory X idler brackets. Essentially the revision is the same less the locator pin as currently equipped. It is listed as XMAINBODYLATE. Thanks to the folks that let me know of the design differences.
This is a more robust design of the Folgertech FT-5 X idler assembly using more commonly acquired 608 bearings also widely used as skateboard bearings designed to be a drop in modular assembly for the originally equipped components. Feedback positive or negative is always welcomed and encouraged "of course if tastefully spoken" as that is how we all learn. If this works for you please show it off by posting a make of it as it is what keeps inspired to do more. If for some reason it doesn't, please let me know and I'll do what I need to to make it work. Thanks to John Folger for the awesome machine he has made so affordable everyone should own one!

Printer:

Folgertech FT-5

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

I used .2 layer height

Infill:

I used 20% but recommend 50% and up.

Notes:

Parts are designed to have the halves mating flanges as flat as possible so orient the lower half upside down so it is touching the bed.

Assembly instructions and bill of materials to follow

Parts list.
1 608 bearing and 1 F608 bearing preferred however 2 standard 608's can be used with a washer between top of pulley and upper bearing.

1 m8 smooth rod 33mm long chamfer each end for idler axle.

1 GT2 20 tooth X 8mm pulley with set screws. Link for these https://www.amazon.com/gp/aw/d/B019GIJ296/ref=mp_s_a_1_1?ie=UTF8&qid=1496123258&sr=8-1&pi=AC_SX236_SY340_FMwebp_QL65&keywords=gt2%2B20t%2B8mm%2Bpulley&dpPl=1&dpID=51s-XR%2B4CcL&ref=plSrch&th=1&psc=1

1 m5 x 10 hex head cap screw and companion t-nut. May have as spares from kit.

4 m3 x 16 hex head cap screws

2 existing m3 drop in t nuts.

Perform post print clean-up of support. Press upper bearing into top cap. Press lower bearing down through idler body and seat in base. Loosen X motor mount bolts to release belt. remove existing X idler top melamine piece and existing idler pulley. slide belt through opening of new X tensioner body. Install pin into bottom bearing through the belt opening. Slide pulley down over pin through belt orienting the pulley retainer end to the top. Prepare top bearing plate by putting 2 m3 screws through the holes in the outside of the plate threading them in just to the mating edge. Install top bearing onto smooth rod and slide top plate down to mate the main body. Tighten the outer screws down just finger tight. put 2 remaining m3 screws down through both parts and start the drop in t-nuts on the screws. install new X idler assembly down over the extrusion centering the locator pin in the lower melamine plate and dropping the t-nuts into the extrusion. tighten down the mounting screws then final tighten the outer m3 screws making sure everything is aligned and flat to each other. Slide the m5 t-nut into the end of the extrusion on the front side lining it up with the hole in the X idler body and install and tighten the m5 bolt. Seat belt in idler pulley and adjust belt tension and lock down motor bolts. While holding X idler pin down in place, move the shuttle back and forth to align the pulley with belt travel then stop when a set screw is visible in screw portal. tighten set screw then move shuttle enough to expose the second set screw in the portal and tighten down. Done! On to the Y idlers.
Designed to be a drop in replacement for the orignal x idler.

description.text:
Use standard 1/2" PVC schedule 40 pipe. I picked up 10 ft of this for I think $2.49 and if you cut into 2.5 ft lengths, you get 3 levels. One row on the floor, and 2 more on the pipes.

Lay X's on the back, Print at .3 mm with supports. 7 shells and 10% infill. Final product feels quite sturdy. I could see this easily supporting 5/6 rows at 2.5 ft lengths. Any higher, or longer pipe, I'd move to more shells for strength.

Fit of the PVC pipe is just tight enough to hold without glue and not tight enough that you can't easily take it back apart with lots of effort.

If you print, I want to see it! Oh..Make sure you turn the lettering on the PVC pipes so that they point down.. A clean white looking pipe looks so much better!

author: JamesT42

print_settings.Notes:: It is important to make each half individually, to prevent breaks and irregularities in the walls.

description.text:
Triskaideka Box V1.5
This is my first try at a "Single Wall Box", and thought I would make something fun. The first print didn't go well, and I learned a lot from it. This is version 1.5, and should work pretty well on most printers. The wall thickness is 0.4mm, the gap is 0.75mm, and gave a nice fit. I recommend printing them separately, so that there are no breaks in the print when it switches between halves. It is designed after a sprocket with thirteen teeth, because I enjoy numbers and engineering. It's big enough for bracelets, but small enough for rings. Could be great for beads and buttons, or other small things too. Not strong enough to toss around, but stronger than you would think. I found that I needed to add a small dot of CA glue here and there, but that is more print settings and filament than anything. I hope to see pictures of your prints, and appreciate honest feedback. I look forward to posting more stuff soon! =^.^=

Printer:

XYZprinting, da Vinci Jr. 1.0

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

Standard Settings

Infill:

Solid

Notes:

It is important to make each half individually, to prevent breaks and irregularities in the walls.
Should need little, if any, Post-Print work. Just enjoy! =^.^=

My first "Single Wall" Box

I used a CAD program to create nested 13 Tooth Sprockets, 20mm thick, and then used Boolean Delete to make the walls. The top and bottom are 67mm Circles, extruded 3mm. I set up the initial print so that both halves would print simultaneously, which was a big mistake. This caused a whole part of each wall to simply not print, but it only cost two teeth on each half to clean up enough to fit beautifully together, so I just lined them up and call them a feature. Besides, 13-2=11, all Prime Numbers, it worked out anyway, lol. A little bit of clean up and modification to V1.0 went a long way, and a small change to print settings went the rest of the way, so I present Triskaideka Box V1.5.
This turned out better than I hoped, and will likely make a bunch of these for gifts in the future. =^.^=

description.text:
This is a 3D printable modification of Mario Carvajal's original Quimbaya 360 panoramic photo head, You can find his work in http://www.mariocarvajal.com http://www.fotografia360.org/ or https://www.kamaradas.com/

This printing has been done in ABS with a 100% infill for it to also be used with heavy cameras. I don't know how hard PLA can be but I suppose it can also be used, the principal parts are 8mm thick. The STLs are ready to print. You only need to add supports on the wheels where the knots go and on the botom of part C.

ABS tends to bend while printing, just in case you find some strange parts in the FreeCAD files.

See the photos to se how I added a fast release mount for the camera.

The instructions on how to put everything together are here:
http://www.mariocarvajal.com/construccion-de-rotula-panoramica-casera-diy-panoramic-head/

The screw that holds part B and C can be a screw with the eliptical plastic head or as in the pictures, a bike fast release screw like the ones on the rires or seat.

With the settings I describe it took me about 30 hours just to print everything.

If you need more info send me a message.

I hope you like it.

comments.text: Why should the rods swing freely?  Won't that cause the print head to also swing freely?
comments.author: McSchweg

comments.text: No. The threaded rods are for the upward / downward movement alone (!). Only the polished rods are for the positioning of the print head. If the threaded rods would also be affixiated at both ends, the possible bending will instantly interfere with the polished rods and wobbling will accur more rather than less. It is an iron rule, but not everyone anticipates it yet.

description.text:
basically...Gteng Artifact fpv wrist monitor watch stripped of its wrist straps, encased in a monocle setup and attached to a set of safety glasses.

holes in the side of main body are guide holes for cutting slots for fresnel lenses (credit card sized ones available on Ebay for pennies, Id suggest the use of two for optimal focus and magnification levels)

parts are fastened together with m3 bolts (2x 10mm for eye piece to main body, 4x 5mm for backplate)

glasses are attached with hot glue (can use epoxy or superglue but be careful to get the glasses sat right before you final fix as unlike hot glue your wont get them off again without destroying something).

once glasses are fitted use some foam padding to get a snug fit round eye socket to prevent light leakage.

whole setup only weighs about 50g so isnt uncomfortable or drags glasses off your face but Id suggest the use of a safety cord from arms around back of head to prevent flinging the glasses off when you turn your head to quickly (remember unlike a full face goggle setup you will still be able to use one eye to see so you can often forget you have the monocle on and turn your head to quickly)

Printer:

poltur XL

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.3

Infill:

30%

I use this to fly my 250's which are by no means slow frames and I am by no means a slow careful pilot so being able to see clearly and accurately is a must during fpv sessions, this setup supplies those needs more than adequately, Im confident you'll be suprised just how well the Gteng performs in this design once you've got it setup to your own preferences.

title: Headphone Stand V1
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I challenged myself by building something that's useful in the shortest amount of time possible from scratch. (Not including print time). It took less than 2 hours to finish the CAD model.

This the first version of the headphone stand, and I would like everyone to build upon this design by making it a lot stronger with more features. (Adding phone stand/charging station/cooler design). Use it for your education/need, learn how you can create things that can benefit everyone.

Also, to make it fun, you should challenge yourself by building something from scratch within the shortest amount of time possible. Let your imagination go to work and think one problem at a time!

Printer Brand:

FlashForge

Printer:

FlashForge Creator Pro

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

Standard

Infill:

15% - 30%

Notes:

Print Notes:

  • Headphone_Leg_v1 is crucial to print at 25% - 35% infill to make sure it does not break, because it will undergo stress.

  • Headphone_Holder_v1 needs support added where there's a rectangular opening depending on how you position the part on your print bed.

Required Material:
  • Screwdriver
  • Sanding file
  • M3.9 Size, 25 mm Long or similar size screw (For Stand & Leg)

  • M3.9 Size, 19 mm Long (For the Leg & Holder) [OPTIONAL]

  • I did not use the 19 mm for my print, because the holder was really tight for the headphone_leg, therefore I just left it assembled without using any screws. You can print the headphone_holder_X and force it in the leg and save yourself a screw.

title: Folgertech FT-5 Y Idler upgrade
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text: This is a more robust design of the Folgertech FT-5 Y idler assembly using more commonly acquired 608 bearings also widely used as skateboard bearings designed to be a drop in modular assembly for the originally equipped components. Feedback positive or negative is always welcomed and encouraged "of course if tastefully spoken" as that is how we all learn. If this works for you please show it off by posting a make of it as it is what keeps inspired to do more. If for some reason it doesn't, please let me know and I'll do what I need to to make it work. Thanks to John Folger for the awesome machine he has made so affordable everyone should own one!

Printer:

Folgertech FT-5

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

I used .2 layer height

Infill:

I used 20% but recommend 50% and up.

Notes:

Parts are designed to have the halves mating flanges as flat as possible so orient the lower half upside down so it is touching the bed. Recommend printing in ABS or higher temperature and strength materials especially if using with a heated build chamber.

Assembly instructions and bill of materials to follow

Parts list

4-608 bearings 8x22x7 commonly used for skateboards.

2-m8 smooth rod x 34mm long. Chamfer both ends for idler axle shaft. Pretty much any type will work.

2-GT2 20 tooth X 8mm pulleys with set screws. https://www.amazon.com/gp/aw/d/B019GIJ296/ref=mp_s_a_1_1?ie=UTF8&qid=1496123258&sr=8-1&pi=AC_SX236_SY340_FMwebp_QL65&keywords=gt2%2B20t%2B8mm%2Bpulley&dpPl=1&dpID=51s-XR%2B4CcL&ref=plSrch&th=1&psc=1

8-m5 x 16 hex head cap screws to replace existing y idler plate screws too short for this use.

8-existing m5 drop in t-nuts.

Perform post printing clean-up of support as necessary. Press a bearing into each top cap and into lower base bearing seats. Loosen Y motor bolts to release belt and remove both existing Y idler top plates and idlers. Remove and reuse the 8 t-nuts. Store away remaining existing parts in a safe place in case this doesn't work. Haha. Prepare top plates by installing m5 x 16 socket head cap screws down through each one. Thread the loop of belt through the opening in each respective Y base while observing proper right/left side orientation. Insert m6 smooth rod axle down through belt loop and into lower bearing being careful not to push the shaft to far or the bearing out of the lower base. Insert the pulley down through the belt loop onto the axle shaft being sure to observe the top to bottom orientation of the pulley. The large pulley body end with the retainer screws should go up. While holding the lower shaft end and bearing in place, install upper cap down onto the axle shaft until base and cap flanges meet. Push all m5 cap screws through the cap and base and loosely install the drop in t-nuts. To ease installation, hold body together and move axle shaft if necessary to be approximately 1 mm above bottom base. Let pulley seat against lower brearing and lightly tighten one of the pulley set screws. Now align all the t-nuts in orientation to the slots in the extrusion and set body down on place. Be sure body is seated flat against all the extrusions and then do the wiggle jiggle twist procedure we're all familiar with to get the t-nuts to seat. I found it is best and easier to lock the front rail screws first. Once solidly locked down, adjust your belt tension and lock your motor screws. Loosen the pulley set screw that you lightly tightened. Next slide the gantry back and forth a few times to center the pulley and belt to pulley. When happy with what it is doing, center a set screw in the set screw window and tighten firmly. Move the gantry to the next screw and also tighten firmly. Check your work and movement of the gantry. Done! Have a beer or drink of choice. On to X
Designed to be a drop in replacements for the orignal y idlers.

description.text:
I'm pushing the limits of obscure parts now...

This is a replacement latch for my Zojirushi Thermos (16oz). You can't see it from the picture because the break is on the other side, but the latch that holds the lid closed cracked along the hinge-pin hole. Unfortunately, I lost the little piece that broke, so I tried my hand at modeling a new one. It turned out pretty sweet, and it works, so that's always nice. I'm posting it here for the very small subset of humans out there who own a 3D printer, frequent Thingiverse, and own a Zojirushi Thermos with a broken latch. Enjoy!

I'm sorry for the lack of pictures or instructions - I really didn't expect this to work first time and I don't want to take things back apart to photograph them. The basic idea is to separate the two halves of the lid (a little prying will get you there). Then push out the pin and install the new latch (DON'T FORGET THE SPRING). Finally, smoosh the two lid halves back together and Bob is your uncle.

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

I used 0.1mm layers.

Infill:

Solid

Notes:

No support needed, although there is some bridging at the top.

I whipped this up in Fusion 360 - my first foray into a real CAD program as I have previously designed all my other models with Sketchup. Anyway, Fusion 360 is really awesome once you get behind the design philosophy. Cheers!
This has been redesigned in Sketchup and sized to fit 10 CR2025 batteries. I also designed a lid to keep the batteries in place.

title: 3D scranner
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Ever since i got my 3D print i have always wanted to make a 3D scanner. I have got a Xbox kinect sensor and have used it to scan things in to the computer but it can only really do large objects, rooms or people. I have also used 123D Catch but it is very hard to get a good scan with just images and without a turntable with set angles. The scanner that I need uses a laser to show the side of the object. This has different problems over the other methods but may work for what I need.

With this method I am using a SLR camera to scan the object into the computer using either 123D Catch, Horus or other software. The can be 2 lasers lines on the object to help scan the object into the computer. The turntable uses a NEMA 17 stepper motor to spin it to different angles. The lasers and stepper motor is all controlled but an Arduino UNO and an A4988 stepper motor controller located under the scanner. This Arduino gets commends either from the computer scanning the object in or a button to rotate the turn table at different angles.
http://tinkersprojects.com/Projects/3d-scanner/

see more what I have done: http://tinkersprojects.com/

description.text:
This is a small organizer that can be used for anything, from pencils and paperclips to buttons and bolts. The organizer features three small pockets in the front, along with one large pocket in the back, for much larger items. The overall shape of the organizer allows for taller objects in the back, such as a pencil or a pad of paper, and shorter objects in the front, such as paperclips or buttons. The organizer has the ability to make your office space, bedroom, bathroom, or garage more organized and less cluttered, which can save time. The walls are thin, creating a shorter print time while remaining strong.

This is the first item I have created that can actually be useful, so please leave some comments and feedback so I can know how to improve my designs. Thanks! And also --- I am saving money to buy a 3D printer so that I can test my designs before I upload them to Thingiverse, so any Tips are appreciated!

remixed_from.author: franklima260
remixed_from.title: Handle for 2.5 mm Allen Key / Hex Key

title: Customizable, Removable Handle for Allen/Hex Wrench/Key

description.text:
A removable, customizable-sized handle for hex keys/allen wrenches. The hex key locks into place when in use, but can easily be removed to use the wrench without the handle, in order to reach tighter spaces. The handle can be custom sized in diameter and length, and sized to any hex key.

This design is based off of JohnSL's popular Customizer design for a zip-tie secured version of this wrench. I also returned to franklima260's original design style, as I liked the small neck at the bottom that makes it look a bit more like a real screwdriver handle.

STL files for 1.5mm, 2.5mm, and 5mm Allen wrenches are included. For any other size, the Customizer should be used (see instructions below).

Printer:

Folgertech 2020 Prusia i3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.2mm

Infill:

50%

Notes:

I used Cura line supports at 25% density "touching everywhere" to support the overhang in the slot; These supports can be easily removed with a thin craft knife; the Allen wrench itself also makes a nice tool to push out any lingering supports. The 50% infill is probably overkill, but creates a nice, solid tool.

For the hex size of the wrench, be sure to measure the maximum diameter of the wrench point-to-point (not flat-to-flat). If only the nominal (flat-to-flat) size of the wrench is known, this can be approximated as hex size = 1.082*nominal size.

The handle diameter and length are probably best left at the default settings, but most values should work fine. A length of around 40mm creates a nice "stubby" screwdriver, depending on the handle diameter.

The "hole delta" is an enlargement factor that increases the size of the slot. My shaky RepRap seemed to produce the best prints at 0.2mm, but higher-precision printers may produce workable prints at .15mm or less.

description.text:
Scoopr - An overengineered solution nobody asked for to a social problem.

Scoopr is a scale with a live-ish web dashboard so you can see how much coffee is left in the office coffeepot since somebody keeps taking the last cup without starting a new pot. Rather than posting passive aggressive signs, we decided to make a passive aggressive open source project.

The name follows Poopr, a bathroom availability project. We pivoted from an output strategy to an input strategy after Poopr suffered from logistical problems and market congestion (battery replacement for the door monitors was tedious, and we're getting a new office with more bathrooms.)

This is the result of a hack day project at my work, which has nothing to do with pooping or scooping.

Hardware requirements: NodeMCU, hx711 breakout board, 5kg load cell, coffee.

STL sources: https://www.tinkercad.com/things/cmAX6IXlBaM

Node MCU lua scripts and firmware blob: https://github.com/checkr/scoopr-firmware - enter your wifi credentials in credentials.lua and set the endpoint for your rails app in timer.lua

Rails app with view: https://github.com/checkr/scoopr - you'll need to tweak the weight of your coffee pot in the CoffeeWeight model. Deploy to heroku as-is or dockerize.

TODO:
Hardware: Mount for the nodeMCU and HX711 - these can easily fit on the bottom plate. A display on the actual device so we can just see how many cups are left without having to go to our phone. (But let's face it, your face was probably already in your phone anyway.)

Software: Post messages to slack when someone takes the last frakking cup. Really should be using MQTT to push the weight when it changes significantly and actioncable to push results to the browser. In practice though, there is about a 1 second latency and it feels very fast. (Unlike a certain somebody in the bathroom. Sigh.)

Printer Brand:

Ultimaker

Printer:

Ultimaker 2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.25mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Printed at 90mm/sec on Ultimaker 2+ modded to 1.75mm @ 220c on hatchbox PLA. The plates are more than strong enough but I'm considering doing some internal cross-beams of solid plastic to increase rigidity further.

title: Beechcraft Bonanza or Baron Glove Box Door

description.text:
Over the years many Bonanza and Baron glove box doors have been cut or discarded to make room for avionics installed in the glovebox. As avionics have evolved they have gotten smaller and more powerful open making it unnecessary to install equipment in the glovebox.

Unfortunately along the way the glovebox door has either been cut or discarded. Replacement doors are hard to find and expensive. This 3D printed door is a nice replacement with a large Beechcraft "B" raised on the door panel.

The latch was made with a knob with an 8-32 threaded shank that goes through the door. The hole in the door needs to be drilled out to 3/32". The a 3/8" by 1" latch was made and trimmed to hold the door tight when closed. An 8-32 hole was drilled and tapped along with a 6-32 set screw to prevent it from turning on the shaft. 6-32 cap screws are used to make the stops for the latch. These holes also need to be drilled to size and tapped for the cap screws.

More information about this thing can be found at https://www.beechtalk.com/forums/viewtopic.php?f=7&t=133721

description.text:
Last year, I bought myself a mountain bike and a couple nice el cheapo accessories to go along with it. One such accessory is a weatherproof zippered case by Gear Beast:

https://www.amazon.ca/Waterproof-Holder-iPhone-Galaxy-Phones/dp/B00ZTJ8LWG/

Case is nice, but even with the (included) foam inserts, my poor OnePlus3 would be WAY too loose inside the case. And by simple eyeballing, I figured the case was thick enough it could accomodate TWO OnePlus3's.

So, personal case scenario: I have both a OnePlus3 and a OnePlus3T, both equipped with identical Spigen Neo Hybrid cases.

I set out to create an insert that would fill out my weatherproof case while allowing me to carry both phones safely. This is what ultimately came out of the process!

One phone per side, cutouts for volume/power buttons on both sides, so phones can be inserted in any orientation, face up or down, doesn't matter.

comments.text: Big thanks for this! I am printing this now to go with my helmet by Killonious. Chest and ab plate are finished. Now for much sanding and gluing. Just as a tip if printing this i recommend scaling chest and back pieces about 5% bigger than abplate as i was unable to fit abs under chest piece at equal scale, although they both fit comfortably. There just wasnt enough of a gap between my body and bottom of chest area. I did chest at 100% and abs at 95 and this worked well for me. For reference i am 5'7" and about 155 lbs.

description.text:
I created this for my local vape shop I frequent. They have all these tester bottles in a corner and I thought it would be great to organize them. IVAPE is name of the shop, but this can double as a statement "I vape".

The holes are measured to 45mm, since most testers are 35-40mm in diameter.

This is the first serious design I did with 123D from AutoDesk. I am probably gonna redesign with an additional level and possible smaller holes for the first level to accommodate smaller 15ml bottles. And probably gonna create a fit together puzzle system so you can lock multiple of these in a row and without the text.

I recommend good bed adhesion since this is fairly a large print 200mm in length.

author: Riggs128

description.text: This is a headphone wrap.

I wanted a secure way to mount a TBS Unify Race HV to my new HyperLite EVO frame. I whipped up this sling to do the job.

Print this in TPU. Use electrical tape to attach the vtx to the sling and slide over the middle standoffs. The sling will grip the standoffs and hold the vtx snugly against the top plate. As a bonus, you can see the LEDs through the top plate hole and you can press on the corner of the Unify to activate the button against the carbon fiber.

For more quadcopter and FPV related content, check out my blog at http://fpvobsession.com/!

If you don't have a printer you can purchase this in a variety of colors from PB3D Creations.

comments.text: Nice simple design. Also nice blog. We are using the realacc X210 as a "spec racer" so some good coverage of that build. I still like to rotate that PDB that comes with the x210 kit and add a pigtail on it since hard mounting the XT60 seems to get damage. http://www.musiccitymultirotorclub.com/index.php/events1/blog/53-music-city-multirotor-club-announces-new-spec-class-racing

I haven't been able to maiden that or the EVO yet since we are cover in a few feet of snow ATM :/.

author: mrmacnology

description.text:
I made this simple rail mount to roughly match the dimensions of the one included with my S550 hexacopter frame. This should clip onto standard camera/accessory rails that are 10mm, and 60mm center to center. It has a drop of about 25mm, and the flat mounting point at the bottom is 30mm wide, and has a pair of 3mm mounting holes, 15mm center to center.
I intend to use these to mount all sorts of stuff to my frame, from the GPS mast on a pair of inverted ones at the back, to an emergency chute hanging off the bottom, between the battery and gimbals.
I hope this is of use to somebody. I made this in tinkercad, by just mashing together solid shapes until i had something of the right dimensions. The model could certainly use some refinement and smoothing, so I would welcome an improved remix!

author: mrmacnology

description.text: I modified the original excellent pixracer basic case, by loosening up the tolerances on the holes in the top for the ESC and ESP wifi pins. Also, I recommend you print this (and the original bottom case) scaled to 101%, seems to fit better that way.

This system is designed to work with pegboard made from wood or pressboard about 1/8" thick, with 1/4" holes on 1" spacing. When your print settings are tuned, the hooks should snap into the pegboard snugly with very little slop. If you are using a thin metal pegboard panel, or a thicker wooden pegboard, the fit may not be as good.

This collection includes:

  • One-piece curved hooks, based on an arc segment, in various lengths and thicknesses
  • One-piece hooked hooks that are flat with a little retaining barb on the end, in various lengths and thicknesses
  • Two-piece long hooks that are stabilized well with a lateral brace piece, in several lengths
  • Arrays of 1, 3, 5, and 7 loops in four diameters. Choose a loop count and upper and lower diameter, print two loop arrays, then attach a pair of rack supports to them to create a rack of screwdriver holders. A single rack support is also provided, in case you just want one loop without a second one below it.
  • Open loops for round-handled tools such as ratchet wrenches and hammers, which let you snap the tool into place.
  • A drill holder system designed to hold a cordless drill. Print one drill holder front, one drill holder rear, and one double brace 5in with pegs. You can also brace it with two lateral braces, but you may have trouble with stability, as the drill is pretty heavy.
  • A model showing only the hook and peg that fit into the pegboard so that you can design whatever hook shape you want using your CAD software of choice, Pegboard-V-Default.STL

There are V and H models included in this collection, which stand for Vertical and Horizontal. The hooks themselves are all V parts. Some are equipped with a rectangular notch, which accepts a mating H part. The loops are H parts that require a V-rack support in order to attach them to the pegboard.

Note: The double brace with pegs parts are only designed to work with the drill holder hooks as of this writing. If you try to assemble two long hooks with a double brace with pegs part, you will find that the double brace's pegs don't line up with any holes. However, two long hooks plus a pegless double brace works great.

Printing tips:

  • I use ABS, but PLA ought to work fine.
  • Adjust your print settings until the pegs fit snugly and the hooks feel firm, not loose and wobbly, after being installed. Get this dialed in before you go printing 20 hooks at once.
  • Do not change the scaling.
  • Increasing your extrusion multiplier (try 1.05 or 1.1) is one way to make the part "swell" and give it a tighter fit.

remixed_from.author: MoonCactus
remixed_from.title: GoPro customizable mounts, and a library to expand

description.text:
This is a GoPro Mount kit for recording art creation. I created it to be able to record my journaling process while traveling. I also created a version that has LED lights to illuminate the sketching here.
Materials:

  1. GoPro camera with in-box mount
  2. 12" 1/8" metal square rod (from hardware store)
  3. 1 1/4" binder clip
  4. #5 Metric hex bolt that is compatible with GoPro fastening bolt threads.
  5. Stiff board or cutting board
  6. Glue

After printing clip insert and GoPro Mount
  1. Insert 1/8" metal rod into GoPro mount - gluing may be necessary
  2. Insert other end of 1/8" metal rod into clip insert
  3. Insert clip insert into handles of binder clip
  4. Attach binder clip to stiff board or hardback of sketchbook
  5. Cut metal rod to length so that camera is centered over board. I found that 8 1/2" is a good length. The longer the rod is, the more it will move the camera.
  6. Attach GoPro camera mount to the printed mount with mounting screw and bolt.

Designed parts using Microsoft 3D Builder app on WIndows 10
  1. For the GoPro mount, I found a mount on Thingiverse that had a GoPro mount on one end and 45° threaded mount on the other end.
  2. In Microsoft 3D Builder, I inserted a cube, changed the dimensions to 1/8"x1/8"x 1" and then subtracted it from the mount at the same location and angle where the 45° threaded mount was.
  3. Using cylinder and cube shapes, I used the subtract and union functions to make a shape that fit inside the handles of the binder clip.

Configure the GoPro Settings using a GoPro mobile App
  1. Video Field of View (FOV): Linear
  2. Auto-Rotation: Down

UPDATED

Ok, so i got to print it and make some measurements, made a new model and am printing it now.
I expect this one will be good enough to use.This was made for my camera, but i made the slot so it can be used on many different types of DSLRs. Please let me know if i can make improvements for you.

I got tired of my camera killing batteries at the wrong time. It has provisions to allow an external power source to be used with battery adapters. So, I decided to make a grip for it that will hold an Inland 5200mAh battery pack that Microcenter sells for $9. This will Greatly extend the battery life, make battery swaps much faster, and use cheap but powerful LiPos made by LG, no more alkaline or unreliable NiMHs.

If you improve on this, let me know so i can link it.

print_settings.Printer:: Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2

title: Oculus Touch Modular Gun Rig [OcToMoGuRi]
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
{Updated 02.14.2017 -- see Custom Section for notes}

The OcToMoGuRi is a severely overly-engineered solution to a simple problem. Since the dawn of Touch mankind has desired to tie their hands to sticks to shoot imaginary steel blow-darts at each other. Now, finally, this future is here.

All kidding aside, I decided to start working on a modular gun rig that just makes sense for the 3D printing community. The Oculus Touch VR hand tracking system in particular has been lacking in cheap, effective designs so I started my focus there. Technically there's nothing stopping anyone from making a compatible screw-bar mount for other systems, and I may do so myself in the future. Of note, this project is open for development in a non-commercial sense; I always think printed designs sound remain free rather than up-charged for online sale.

The main screw-bar and thumb screws are the basis of this project. The threads are sturdy M20x2.5 M-tooth ANSI style, and if you're lucky enough to use metric you may even find the same components in a local hardware store for metal components. This specific thread type makes for a lot of friction fitting, such that with plastic at least, the thumb screws can be counter-tightened to either side of an attachment and it will hold damn near forever.

Attachments should fit a 20mm tall by 12.25mm wide (and in my case 50mm long) slot. The fit can be a bit snug if you like, as you can move the parts around with the assistance of thumb screws if needed. The tighter, the sturdier. Just don't go so tight that you strip the threads from the screw-bar. For reference, I've used 3mm thickness for the walls of my attachment sliders and seen zero flex or failures so far since they were mostly solid. This seems like the magic starting point.

The Oculus Touch components are printed a tad thinner where possible to reduce the occlusion of the controller tracking rings. I've tried even a tad thicker and seen noticeably worse results, and thinner seems to be too weak without printing solid plastic. You can try to tweak the models to fit your needs, but I think I found a good balance here. However this complicates printing by design, so please check the print and post sections for details.

I'd love to hear feedback so I can tweak my design or add extra components. Currently planned is an RIS rail block for fitting custom stocks and additional grips. I'd love to hear about more ideas. Have fun!

Printer Brand:

Wanhao

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

Variable 10-20%

Notes:

Note that I use Simplify 3D, so some terminology may not match your own software of choice. I'll try to stay general. Also note that this print relies on a mid-large format printer without modifying models, but splitting the models is very, very acceptable in terms of end-quality and strength.

Materials: I designed this print to use ABS, as it has a bit of flex and can stand accidental wall-smashes. As such, the STL files are sized for a pretty typical 1.25% shrinkage. This shouldn't affect the end results for other materials, but will affect the dimensions should you design your own parts.

Screw-Bar: Print as many as needed to your desired length, four recommended. For the full layout you will likely need four of these; without the butt stock you only need three, and for compact SMG sizing you can even barely get away with two. Print this bad boy vertically, nub screw end pointing upward. 0.2mm height works perfectly for a standard 0.4mm nozzle. No supports should be needed. I recommend using three outer walls, three floors, and three ceilings for the model to strengthen threads. The outer walls specifically help with layer-toLayer adhesion of the screw threads. Infill can be low (10-15%) for this part, but as there's not much time added and this part is under the most stress, I recommend 20% or more for this one. If you have the ability to do multiple processes like in Simplify3D, I wholly recommend printing the lowest 12mm and the upper 12mm (143mm and up) so they fill completely solid. With a lot of materials the male and female screw bits can print too thick and may crush each other, breaking them free. Printing solid prevents breakage. This should only add about 40-50 minutes to each print.

Thumb Screw: Two needed per attachment. Follow the same instructions for the Screw-Bar, only you'll need to print two of these per component you plan on adding to the rail. If printing a bunch with ABS, you may want to keep the bed temperature lower to prevent warping since these are thin.

Left/Right Gantry: Two needed, one for each hand. These parts are similar, but slightly different for exact fit. Mirror this part on any axis to get a left and right version. Technically you can print either gantry and the cups will still fit, just off center. Again, 0.2mm height works fine for this part. Use supports to aid the lower curves, though they print mostly fine without. These are designed to print on a whole 200x200mm bed, taking up about 185x160mm to be precise. Infill can be about 15% without any noticable hit, suposing you use three outer walls as well. In this case the outer walls provide a tremendous amount of strength, especially in the corners. If you use a smaller printer, slice up this part into the four corners and avoud slicing the angled section and you should be fine from a structural standpoint.

Left/Right Handle Cups: One needed per gantry. These should aim to be as solid as possible. I printed with four outer walls thickness and 30% infill to connect the inner and outer walls, and this worked well. Realistically though, three walls thickness and 20% infill (of a smaller pattern, for more contact points) should do just fine and may allow easier insertion and removal of your Touch controllers by way of a slight flex. If your STL file loads at an angle, rotate the model to print with the open side straight up; Mine load in requiring a -60 degree X-axis rotation, for example. Supports are not required but make for a smoother graded curve on the outside, which may make for easier gripping of the cup.

Sliding Brackets: One needed per attachment. Print these with an open side facing up. They can print with low infill but should have thicker than normal walls. 15% infill and three walls thickness worked alright, but I would probably go 10% and four walls for a sturdier build next time. The fit is what matters most here, as the part doesn't truly allow for flex in the first place by design.

Stock Body: This should print very much like the gantries. If splitting to fot on a smaller printbed, I recommend slicing it about halfway down the long edge to allow for solid glue points and minimal reduction in structure.

Stock Butt Plate: This is intended to print with the flat end touching the build plate. This part requires at least 15% infill in my testing or else the curves warp or shift while building. Effectively the infill works as a surface for the near-constant ceiling printing of the curved top. Wall thickness isn't much of a concern here as the whole part is cylindrical in shape and very strong.

Assembly

This design was created with the intent of gluing components together. If printing with ABS as recommended, a dab of acetone to each connecting surface allows the parts to fuse into solid plastic. The same applies technically to PET and PETG, though I haven't tried this myself. If using PLA, use MEK or methyl acetate if you can find it. If you can't, you can try heat-welding the parts or good old-fashioned super glue. If choosing to use actual glue, I cannot recommend sanding the connecting surfaces rough and then using water-activated Gorilla Glue hardly enough-- the hold will be about as strong as ABS with acetone welding.

Screw-bars assemble exactly with the smaller screws. For added strength I highly recommend loading the threads with either thread locking glue or the solvent for your plastic (acetone in the case of ABS). This will allow the parts to form one solid bar.

Once all attachments are assembled, screw a thumb screw onto the rail. Move it to the desired location, then slide on the attachment. Follow up with another thumb screw. Tighten the screws against both sides of the attachment until snug enough that friction holds them in place, but not so hard that you bust the threads. If you do, the thumb screws were designed as a cheap point of failure so they would be easy to replace. Gluing/welding the thumb screws should not be necessary, and is optional. I recommend keeping the front hand at the least unglued so that you can adjust as needed per gun used, as this becomes important in games like Onward where LMGs require longer grip stances.

And that's it! Enjoy your new Oculus Touch Modular Gun Rig!

This was my second project using Autodesk Fusion 360. The initial protytype was, believe it or not, built in Microsoft 3D Builder which comes with Windows 10. After issued with that design (which held the parts from below and blocked reloading animations), I decided to try out Fusion 360 since it's been getting good press.

I'll upload the design file soon for everyone to use once I've cleaned up some of the various small adjustments in the build history.

Valentine's Update [02.14.2017]:

As a way to say "I love you guys!" I've added a few more parts.

There is now an Extension component that can be glued or welded to the top (or side if you so wish) of any of the 5cm long brackets. This part allows the use of an additional Screw-Bar and Thumbscrews to square the entire frame as well as provide offset triangular absorption of torque forces on the attachments. While not necessary if printed properly, this Extension piece does provide much more strength than really ever required for the Screw-Bars and takes something slightly within breakage margins and gives it some buffer space. You can also technically add more Extensions infinitely until you are satisfied with the overkill.

For convenience and strength I've added DoubleGantryBracket and DoubleStockBracket parts as well. If you don't have the strongest of glues or can't weld your material with solvents, I would recommend this option.

Only one day old and already there's improvements! Have fun, ladies and gents.
